children.value: Software Developer with 20 years of experience across the full software development lifecycle. Proven leadership in both agency and SaaS startup environments. Foster a collaborative and growth-oriented work ethic, with a passion for mentoring and knowledge sharing. Highly organised and analytical, with a demonstrated ability to quickly learn and adapt to new technologies.
(experience with Symfony and Zend, React, TypeScript)
(AWS, DigitalOcean and Google Cloud, Docker and Terraform)

props.:content: ["npx nuxi@latest init -t themes/docus","cd docs","npm install","npm run dev"]

children.value: I have extensive experience in API design, microservices and SPAs.
I managed the development and integration for high-load scalable systems and large-scale, high-traffic environments.
Proven expertise with database performance tuning and data retrieval and storage optimization.
10+ years working with various AWS products (S3, EC2, EBS, Lambda, RDS and Aurora, SQS, SES).
FIrm believer of continuous integration approaches, automated testing and deployment, code style checking, automated load testing.
Implemented error and performance monitoring solutions to maintain system reliability and performance.

contents.title: Cache If Exists
contents.description: A very useful snippet to cache only existing results

children.value: When working with either heavy queries or external APIs, caching the result can be a massive performance gain. Caching not-so frequently changing data is not just cost savings on the server side, but a much better user experience for our clients.

One caveat is that sometimes these scenarios can result empty results, for a variatey of reasons. The external API can be down, the query can yield no result yet. We most likely don't want to cache the empty results (or error responses), and serve no results for the users, or prevent any further attempts for a lengthy period.
facade, the following neat little snippet can be a solution:

props.className: language-php shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai

children.value: Usage is the same as the standard Laravel cache call:

props.className: language-php shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
> cache()->rememberIfExists('fubar', 300, fn() => 'fubar')
= "fubar"

> cache()->has('fubar')                                   
= true

> cache()->pull('fubar')                                  
= "fubar"

> cache()->rememberIfExists('fubar', 300, fn() => null)
= null

> cache()->has('fubar')                                
= false

> cache()->pull('fubar')                               
= null

children.value: html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .sepia .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-sepia);background: var(--shiki-sepia-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-sepia-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-sepia-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-sepia-text-decoration);}html.sepia .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-sepia);background: var(--shiki-sepia-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-sepia-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-sepia-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-sepia-text-decoration);}

contents.title: Laravel Pipelines
contents.description: A tale of Laravel Pipelines, form requests and the service container

children.value: In one of my regular code cleaning sessions I found a piece of code in our controller very similar to this picture:
It looks clean and readable, but the code just went on and on, and made the understanding of the
code much harder than it needs to be.

In this case all I needed to know was that we have an incomin request with parameters, and we have to filter our query based on the different parameters.
There is absolutely no need to keep all the implementation details in the controller.
We can extract our various filters to pipes, and send our base query through them:

props.className: language-php shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
class BookingController extends Controller
{
    public function index(ListBookingsRequest $request): AnonymousResourceCollection
    {
        $bookings = app(Pipeline::class)
            ->send(Booking::query())
            ->through(pipes: [
                FilterByDateRange::class,
                FilterByRescheduleIdentifier::class,
                FilterByGroupIdentifier::class,
                FilterBySequenceIdentifier::class,
                FilterByBookingFormIdentifier::class,
                FilterByClients::class,
                FilterByStatus::class,
                FilterByTransportRequirement::class,
                FilterByRegion::class,
                FilterByAllocation::class,
                FilterByUuid::class,
                FilterOnlyTrashed::class,
                OrderBookings::class,
                SearchBookings::class,
            ])
            ->thenReturn()
            ->paginate();

        return BookingResource::collection($bookings);
    }
}

children.value: The problem arises when we need to pass multiple arguments to our filter classes, in our cases we need to pass the
in order to extract the filter parameters:

props.className: language-php shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai

children.value: One option is to use DTOs, constructed from the base query, and the various request fields we need.

The other option is to rely on Laravel's service container to inject the request instance to our filters.
By simply typing a
in our consturctor, we instruct Laravel to inject the current form request:

props.className: language-php shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai

children.value: as a type, so we have access to the

method.
Here's our redacted form request class:

props.className: language-php shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai

children.value:
There is only one problem with this approach,which we learnt the hard way.
Laravel will inject a
instance of the request for every filter class instance.
For two reasons in our form request: our
method and the various rules will execute database queries for each instance of the request.
In our case 5 queries per request instance used in 14 different filters:
While this was a fairly obscure bug to track down, the fix is relatively easy:
Do not rely on the service container, but

props.className: language-php shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
class BookingController extends Controller
{
    public function index(ListBookingsRequest $request): AnonymousResourceCollection
    {
        $bookings = app(Pipeline::class)
            ->send(Booking::query())
            ->through(pipes: [
                new FilterByRescheduleIdentifier($request),
                new FilterByGroupIdentifier($request),
                new FilterBySequenceIdentifier($request),
                new FilterByBookingFormIdentifier($request),
                new FilterByClients($request),
                new FilterByDate($request),
                new FilterByDateRange($request),
                new FilterByStatus($request),
                new FilterByTransportRequirement($request),
                new FilterByRegion($request),
                new OrderBookings($request),
                new SearchBookings($request),
                new FilterByAllocation($request),
                new FilterByUuid($request),
                new FilterOnlyTrashed($request),
            ])
            ->thenReturn()
            ->paginate();

        return BookingResource::collection($Booking);
    }
}

children.value: html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .sepia .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-sepia);background: var(--shiki-sepia-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-sepia-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-sepia-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-sepia-text-decoration);}html.sepia .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-sepia);background: var(--shiki-sepia-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-sepia-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-sepia-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-sepia-text-decoration);}

contents.title: Vue Props
contents.description: How to pass writeable properties to child components

children.value: It is a fairly common scenario in any system that the frontend receives some initial data from a backend, and then modifies and sends it back.

If the UI is more complex, and consist of nested elements, usually the parent component gets the data, and passes down to its children as properties.
Once the child modifies it, it has to push back the changes to the parent component responsible for the API communication.
Vue actually doesn't make it simple to achive this, with the readonly properties.
The child component must be able to recieve an initial value
It also must be able to reflect any changes to this value later
And finally must be able to change this data, and communicate this changes to its parent
Here is a simple example of a parent components, having a reactive
property, passed down to it's child:

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai

children.value: The naive implementation of the children is to also have a property called

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
<template>
  <Card>
    <template #content>
      <InputNumber v-model="props.counter" />
    </template>
    <template #footer>
      <Button @click="props.counter++">Increment</Button>
      <Button @click="props.counter--">Decrement</Button>
    </template>
  </Card>
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import InputNumber from 'primevue/inputnumber'
import Card from 'primevue/card'
import Button from 'primevue/Button'
import { computed } from 'vue'

const props = defineProps({
  counter: {
    type: Number,
    required: true
  }
});
</script>

children.value: There is one massive problem with this:
We can change our implementation that the children also have a reactive
variable, and maybe copy out the initial value of the property:

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
<template>
  <Card>
    <template #content>
      <InputNumber v-model="counter" />
    </template>
    <template #footer>
      <Button @click="counter++">Increment</Button>
      <Button @click="counter--">Decrement</Button>
    </template>
  </Card>
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import InputNumber from 'primevue/inputnumber'
import Card from 'primevue/card'
import Button from 'primevue/Button'
import { ref } from 'vue'

const props = defineProps({
  counter: {
    type: Number,
    required: true
  }
});

const counter = ref(props.counter);
</script>

children.value: While this solution eliminates the problem with not being able to update the counter from within the child component, and also receives the initial value from the parent component, it won't react if it gets updated in the parent:
Making a field of the props reactive

A common solution to this is something called writeable computed property, which involves a computed variable, where the getter part returns the property directly, while the setter part emits an event to the parent component, and delegates the responsibility of updating the data.

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
<template>...</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import InputNumber from 'primevue/inputnumber'
import Card from 'primevue/card'
import Button from 'primevue/Button'
import { ref } from 'vue'

const props = defineProps({
  counter: {
    type: Number,
    required: true
  }
});

const emit = defineEmits(['update:counter']);

const counter = computed({
  get() {
    return props.counter
  },
  set(value) {
    emit('update:counter', value)
  }
});
</script>

children.value: This solves all our initial requirements, it can receive initial data from the parent, can update the value, and this update is emitted to the parent.
This is a common solution, as a matter of fact the

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
<template>...</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import InputNumber from 'primevue/inputnumber'
import Card from 'primevue/card'
import Button from 'primevue/button'
import { useVModel } from '@vueuse/core'

const props = defineProps({
    counter: {
        type: Number,
        required: true
    }
});

const emit = defineEmits(['update:counter']);
const counter = useVModel(props, 'counter', emit);
</script>

children.value: There is only one big issue with this. This component can not work on it's own, it always relies on it's parent to update the data.
If the update event is not handled in the parent, the children
can't update its own internal state
This can be easy to overlook, and might be hard to debug.
In general I'm not a huge fan of watchers, but in this case this one seems to be the final solution:
The children can get an initial data from its parent
If the data is changed in the parent, it will be reflected in the children
The children can modify the data internally
be emitted to the parent - but it is not a requirement for the child component to work

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
<template>
    <Card>
        <template #title>Child counter: {{ counter }}</template>
        <template #content>
            <InputNumber v-model="counter" />
        </template>
        <template #footer>
            <Button @click="counter++">Increment</Button>
            <Button @click="counter--">Decrement</Button>
        </template>
    </Card>
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import InputNumber from 'primevue/inputnumber'
import Card from 'primevue/card'
import Button from 'primevue/button'
import { ref, watch, type Ref } from 'vue'

const props = defineProps({
    counter: {
        type: Number,
        required: true
    }
});

const emit = defineEmits(['update:counter']);
const counter: Ref<number> = ref(props.counter);

watch(() => props.counter, (value: number) => counter.value = value);
watch(() => counter.value, (value: number) => emit('update:counter', value));

</script>

children.value: html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .sepia .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-sepia);background: var(--shiki-sepia-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-sepia-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-sepia-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-sepia-text-decoration);}html.sepia .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-sepia);background: var(--shiki-sepia-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-sepia-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-sepia-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-sepia-text-decoration);}

contents.title: Git Worktrees
contents.description: How to work on multiple git branches simultaneously

children.value: In the recent weeks I am working on a big feature of our system, with a lot of changes, and a decent development time. But since life doesn't stop, I still have to respond to maintenance requests and bug fixes, which means I frequently have to switch between branches. The initial method I learnt many years ago was to commit or stash my changes, checkout the other branch, do the fix, commit, push, and then come back to the original code.
Needless to say, this is a lot of switching, stashing, committing - a lot of room for errors and making a mess in the repository.
Couple of weeks ago I came across an article, which introduced a very interesting concept to me, Git Worktrees.

This feature basically allows me to checkout multiple branches of the same repository, but without the overhead of checking out the whole project again. The worktree points to a folder in your file system, and references a branch, but working from the same clone.
To see all available worktrees, you can use the

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
git worktree list
/Users/balazssebesteny/Sites/balazs.sebesteny.com  53b470d [main]

children.value: Let's assume you are working on a feature, but an urgent bugfix request came in. To create a worktree for an existing branch, you can use the following :

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
git worktree add ../balazs.sebesteny.com-bugfix-01 bugfix-01
Preparing worktree (new branch 'bugfix-01')
branch 'bugfix-01' set up to track 'origin/bugfix-01'.
HEAD is now at 53b470d SEO

children.value: If we take a look into the new folder created, we can see that there is no

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
ls -la ./
total 1496
drwxr-xr-x@ 18 balazssebesteny  staff     576 25 Jul 13:40 .
drwxr-xr-x  40 balazssebesteny  staff    1280 25 Jul 13:40 ..
-rw-r--r--@  1 balazssebesteny  staff     104 25 Jul 13:40 .git
-rwxr-xr-x@  1 balazssebesteny  staff      88 25 Jul 13:40 .gitignore
-rw-r--r--@  1 balazssebesteny  staff      53 25 Jul 13:40 .npmrc
-rwxr-xr-x@  1 balazssebesteny  staff     952 25 Jul 13:40 README.md
...

children.value: This contains the reference to the original clone's
folder, and ensures that our usual Git commands are working:

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
cat ..git
gitdir: /Users/balazssebesteny/Sites/balazs.sebesteny.com/.git/worktrees/balazs.sebesteny.com-bugfix-01

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
git status
On branch bugfix-01
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/bugfix-01'.

nothing to commit, working tree clean

children.value: At the end of the day we can implement our fix in this folder, test it, commit and push it, and done.
Creating a new worktree along with a new branch
If we didn't create out bugfix branch in our repository provider UI, we can always do it like this:

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
git worktree add ../balazs.sebesteny.com-bugfix-02 origin/main -b bugfix-02
Preparing worktree (new branch 'bugfix-02')
branch 'bugfix-02' set up to track 'origin/main'.
HEAD is now at 53b470d SEO

children.value: Once we finished our work in the extra worktrees, we can simply remove them:

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-dark github-light monokai
props.code:
git worktree list
/Users/balazssebesteny/Sites/balazs.sebesteny.com            53b470d [main]
/Users/balazssebesteny/Sites/balazs.sebesteny.com-bugfix-01  53b470d [bugfix-01]
/Users/balazssebesteny/Sites/balazs.sebesteny.com-bugfix-02  53b470d [bugfix-02]

git worktree remove ../balazs.sebesteny.com-bugfix-01
git worktree remove ../balazs.sebesteny.com-bugfix-02

git worktree list
/Users/balazssebesteny/Sites/balazs.sebesteny.com  53b470d [main]

children.value: The big advantage is that we don't have to clone the repository multiple times, the
folder is shared, our worktrees will use the same git config, if you fetch in any of the worktrees it will fetch in all, etc.
One arguable disadvantage is that you will end up multiple top level directories, which can be inconvenient from an organising point of view.
And one more sidenote, one branch can only have one worktree.

children.text: Creating a new worktree along with a new branch
